title: Chapter 91
content:
Chapter 91

◎Avoiding Marriage◎

The little princess's formal name had not yet been decided. She was the first daughter born after the emperor ascended the throne, and everyone doted on her greatly. The more this was the case, the more careful one had to be. She was affectionately called Tonger, a name that conveyed closeness and endearment.

Huìyīn had been reading for too long in the early morning, which caused her neck to become sore. Zhān'er immediately began to massage her and used a small mallet to tap her back. As he grew older, Zhān'er seemed to have a gentle and filial personality—very sensible and obedient.

"Are you tired from all the tapping, sweetie? How about I get you your favorite walnut tea?" Huìyīn said, holding her son's hand.

Zhān'er, being truly sensible, shook his head. "There's no need, Mother. I just came because I thought you might have a sore shoulder. Yesterday, after I went horse riding, I felt sore all over, but the wet nurse helped me massage, and I felt better."

"I see, where were you sore yesterday? Let me take a look," Huìyīn knew that Lǐ Chéng's expectations for their sons were to be well-versed in both literature and martial arts. Luckily, both her sons were healthy, but she knew better than to interfere with their martial arts training.

Now that Lǐ Chéng had only recently ascended the throne, if there were to be another war, they couldn't let the court officials and generals lead them by the nose. If the emperor were proficient in both civil and military strategies, the court would be stable for at least three generations. This was also why Huìyīn was still willing to have children—because their family truly had a throne to inherit.

Zhān'er pointed to his thighs and back, and Huìyīn put down her book to personally massage her son. She asked, "These days, your father often inquires about your studies, and with your younger sister's birth, I've inevitably neglected you. If there's anything you don't understand, just tell me."

"There's nothing I don't understand, Mother. If I don't understand something, my elder brother teaches me. Yesterday, my elder brother even specially gave me some medicine," Zhān'er said with a smile.

Huìyīn nodded. "I'm glad to see that you and your brother are still so harmonious, but you are also my son. You don't have to be so sensible all the time. If something happens, you must tell me."

As the children grew older, they could no longer live in the side halls and had to move to the Prince's Quarters. This was ancestral tradition, and even Lǐ Chéng couldn't keep his sons by his side all the time. In ordinary official families, boys who grew older would move to the outer courtyards, let alone princes who needed to set an example for the nation.

Zhān'er was delighted to hear this. "Mother, you can visit my palace when you have time. I have many things to tell you."

"Alright, I'll wait until you're done with school tomorrow and come to see you, alright?" Now that there were three children, fairness was essential.

Zhān'er was sweeter than if he had eaten honey. Huìyīn then accompanied him to play touhu (a traditional game), and soon after, Jǐng'er arrived. Huìyīn smiled. "Your brother knew I had a sore neck and remembered how he felt better after a massage from horse riding yesterday, so he came to help me. I was just wondering when you would arrive."

"I went to find my second brother, intending to come together, but he arrived first. Mother, I heard from Father that you're going to perform the sericulture ceremony?" Jǐng'er asked.

Huìyīn nodded. "The sericulture ceremony involves honoring the Silkworm Goddess, harvesting mulberries, and presenting cocoons for silk production. Officials from the Ministry of Rites will handle it, and I'll just go to perform the ritual."

Jǐng'er clearly wasn't there to talk about that and seemed hesitant. Huìyīn dismissed the servants and asked, "What is it? Do you have something to tell me?"

"It's not a big deal, but the other day, Guō Xìng (Earl Guo's son) entered the palace, and I spoke with him for a while. He seems quite resistant to the marriage with the Yǔwén family. During our conversation, I couldn't tell if he wanted me to convey to you his wish to stop this marriage."

Huìyīn looked at her son with great satisfaction. "You've grown up. It's good that you didn't rush to take sides but instead understood the underlying intentions."

Jǐng'er hurriedly said, "It's all thanks to your teachings, Mother."

Children in the palace tend to mature early, and this was indeed true. Her younger son knew to come early to please her, and her elder son confided in her, showcasing his abilities. It was not a bad thing for them to be so shrewd at their age.

"There's no need to meddle in the affairs of subjects. If you take sides, it won't be good no matter which side you choose. You should always be the one who makes the final decision and doesn't intervene in trivial matters. Moreover, breaking up a marriage is not acceptable. I know you're a straightforward child, but his parents have their reasons for arranging this marriage. As royals, we must not interfere in the family matters of non-royal officials." Huìyīn certainly understood young love, but people change over time, and if they really couldn't live together, there would be ways to resolve it.

Jǐng'er worriedly said, "Mother, what if Guō Xìng runs away? With his current resistance and inability to defy his father, he might do something drastic if he's unhappy."

Huìyīn stroked her son's head. "Maybe that could be beneficial."

Jǐng'er was startled.

Huìyīn explained in detail, "An emperor's primary role is to maintain balance and prevent internal strife. If they become too united, they might turn against the emperor. So, some minor friction between them could be beneficial to us, don't you think?"

"But Guō Xìng grew up with me," Jǐng'er said, noting that his mother usually took good care of Guō Xìng.

Huìyīn smiled. "If I were an ordinary aunt, I would do my best to help him, but we are different; we are royalty. He stayed with us back then due to imperial strategy, and it remains true today. What I'm telling you now is for your ears only; don't tell anyone."

Family ties often take a backseat in the struggle for power. The Cuī family's hesitation—wasn't it an attempt to rebel? And they are even direct uncles. The marriage between the Guō family and Yǔwén may have been meant to strengthen alliances.

Jing'er nodded secretly, then stood up and said, "Thank you for your guidance, Mother."

"However, this matter is ultimately just a strategy. As the crown prince, you should focus more on the livelihood of the people. If you can control those people while still ensuring their well-being, your policies will be executed smoothly in the future. That is the true way to be a ruler." Huiyin said.

The mother and son exchanged a few more words. Seeing that Zhan'er had fallen asleep on the bed, Huiyin said to Jing'er, "Your father has summoned you. You should go ahead. Let your brother rest here a bit longer. He went riding horses yesterday and felt uncomfortable. He specifically wanted some comfort from me."

Originally, Jing'er thought his brother was being unfair, coming to curry favor so early by himself, but what his mother said made sense. His brother was still a child. Sometimes, when he was wronged, he just wanted his mother's comfort.

Jing'er then said, "I will go then."

"Go ahead," Huiyin waved her hand and went to her younger son. She tucked the thin quilt around him. It was still the end of February, and although the palace had heated floors, Zhan'er was sweating on his forehead. She helped wipe it and, unable to resist, she kissed her little son on the forehead, sitting beside him, waiting for him to wake up.

Her little daughter, Tonger, was only a month old and was still at the age where she would sleep after feeding. When Zhan'er woke up, it felt as though he was very young again, with his mother taking care of him.

"Erlang, let's go see your sister. Come on," Huiyin, who had a somewhat peculiar personality when she was young, was fortunate that her children were all sensible. Therefore, she was very patient with them.

Tonger had just finished feeding and was sleeping soundly. Zhan'er whispered to Huiyin, "Mother, was I this small when I was young?"

"You were just like that. When you were little, you loved blowing bubbles. I often called your brother to come and see," Huiyin mentioned the past, seeing Zhan'er's face turn red, and decided not to continue.

At dinner time, Li Cheng came over and saw them talking. He looked at his younger son affectionately, "It's true that you are close to your mother. I couldn't find you anywhere."

Zhan'er quickly bowed again, and Li Cheng gestured for him to sit down.

"I didn't expect Your Majesty to come. Since you are here, I'll have the small kitchen add a few more dishes. How about that?" Huiyin quickly stood up.

Li Cheng smiled faintly, "I'll just have some rice porridge. I had Yunnan's tribute dishes at noon, and after eating so much meat, I can't eat anything else now."

"In that case, I'll have them make some small dishes for the porridge. Just wait a moment, Zhan'er, accompany your father," Huiyin sent someone to the kitchen.

"Prepare some dried bamboo shoots, dried fish, and stir-fried mixed nuts, and remember not to peel the hazelnuts. Also, we have received many fresh and sweet cabbages from our Jizhou estate. I find them good, so have them make some steamed buns."

After giving the instructions, she returned. The three of them played a drinking game and waited until the dishes were all served before they started eating. Indeed, when one is tired of rich food, light and sweet dishes feel very good. Normally finding some vegetable dishes fishy, Li Cheng actually ate two. The porridge was quite thin, almost like drinking water, and Li Cheng had two more bowls before stopping.

While they were eating happily, the Guo family had their own thoughts. Guo Xing had been raised by Huiyin for several years and behaved differently from others. Because back in Huaiyin Mansion, when Huiyin was still a princess, the empress treated her two children with great respect. Whether it was major matters like what to study or minor ones like what food to eat, she always listened to the children's opinions.

In their own family, it was completely the father's word that counted. He often scolded them, and the stepmother was very polite and always deferred to the father.

"Young Master, please eat a few more bites. You haven't touched the food," the servant who had been attending Guo Xing since he was young felt distressed.

Despite his handsome appearance, the young master was to be married to an unattractive woman. It was truly Lord Guo who was causing trouble.

Guo Xing put down his chopsticks, "I'm going to ride horses. Have someone bring my horse over."

The horse was a gift from the empress. He hoped that if the crown prince could speak favorably on his behalf in front of the empress, this marriage might be called off. Although the hope was slim, if it were agreed, it would be wonderful.

While he was thinking this, Jiang Bipbo was speaking with Lady Yuwen. Their horoscopes matched, and they were considered a perfect match. The two ladies were having a meal together and were very cordial with each other.

Lady Yuwen smiled, "I'm not as close to the empress as you are. We don't live in Xuzhou, and even when I met the empress before, I didn't know how to flatter her. In the future, please teach me more."

"You're too kind. The empress is the most amiable person. Our families have been close for generations, and now we are in-laws. If you have any questions, I will certainly share everything I know," Jiang Bipbo thought to herself that she didn't even know what kind of person the empress was.

She used to think the empress was a virtuous helper to the emperor or a warm-hearted person, but it seemed not. The empress was impossible to define, completely unpredictable.

Other women needed to vent, complain, or even be jealous or greedy for power. The empress lacked nothing. In terms of appearance, she was top-notch, and her husband only wanted to marry her, not even having a concubine. She also successfully gave birth to a son. She was not greedy, and the emperor was delivered to her.

What could possibly move someone who has everything?

Madame Yu saw that despite her status, Jiang Bipbo remained humble and considerate, which pleased her even more. As a daughter-in-law, the husband is secondary; the most important thing is to find a good mother-in-law. If the mother-in-law is good, life will be comfortable. Seeing that Guo Xing's stepmother was young and kind, and since she rarely interfered, Huiyin believed her daughter’s life would be easier.

As the saying goes, 'When brothers are united, they can conquer anything.' The same applies to families. If there are disagreements, big troubles will arise sooner or later.

It was also said that on the third day of the third month, after dressing properly, Huiyin went to perform the sericulture ceremony. Almost all the nobles and titled ladies came to witness the event. She had moved in two days earlier to personally reel the silk and planned to take it home to spin into thread and weave a garment herself.

Li Cheng even commissioned a painter to create a special illustration of the sericulture ceremony, turning it into a grand affair. From then on, when he was working in the Duanning Hall, he would occasionally call Huiyin over to personally teach her how to handle official duties.

However, in the process, Huiyin also discovered her own shortcomings. She said to Li Cheng, "I realized that I don’t truly enjoy organizing others. If you assign me a task, I can certainly do it well, but if you ask me to socialize all day, I find it troublesome."

Understanding people’s intentions is exhausting, and the constant negotiations and compromises only add to the fatigue.

Li Cheng smiled and said, "Now you understand my dilemma. I'm the same as you. Sometimes, during military campaigns, one person would swear by one principle, and another by a different one. They all say a person must be decisive, but how can anyone know everything? So, you have to talk repeatedly, afraid that people will see through your ignorance. It's really annoying."

"It seems we both have the soul of a carefree hermit, but we don’t have the luxury of stepping away from our responsibilities," Huiyin covered her mouth and laughed.

Li Cheng put his hands on her shoulders and said, "You don’t need to be overly formal when you come here, or worry about overhearing something. In the future, learn from how I handle things. As the saying goes, learning by observation is the best way. You don’t have to learn so much right away. Just listen for now."

"Yes," Huiyin replied. She had mostly handled internal affairs before, and at most, she would prepare in advance and offer some advice on external matters. But actually managing a country was an entirely different matter, like taking one step but needing to plan a hundred steps ahead.

Seeing Huiyin so obedient, like a female student, he playfully lifted her chin, "Since you're so well-behaved, how will you thank me?"

"I've been out of confinement for three months now, and my body has fully recovered. You can come over tonight."

Skipping the details of their intimate moments, by day, Huiyin’s eyes sparkled like spring water, and her cheeks naturally flushed pink, which reignited Li Cheng’s desire, though he restrained himself.

Li Cheng got up and said, "Recently, I'm planning to establish a secret intelligence bureau that belongs to me personally. They will be responsible for spying on everything exclusively for me. What do you think?"

"That’s a good thing. If it’s exclusively for Your Majesty, no one below will dare to hide anything from you," Huiyin replied.

Li Cheng nodded and said, "That’s exactly what I thought. I won’t unnecessarily doubt my court officials. After all, people have desires and emotions. How many officials truly serve the people rather than themselves? As long as the person is capable, their flaws are irrelevant. But they can’t just boast without doing any work, or go too far."

In the officialdom, officials protect each other, and over time, policies get blocked. The emperor has to come up with his own solutions.

It took almost a year of effort before Li Cheng began to establish his personal intelligence unit. By then, Tonger had just turned one and was beginning to speak.

Sitting on the carpet, Huiyin watched her daughter stumble towards her and quickly reached out. Her soft daughter crashed into her arms.

"Mother..." Tonger called in a baby voice.

Huiyin pinched her daughter's lotus-like arms and said, "Hearing you call me ‘Mother’ just melts my heart."

"Where's Father?" Tonger looked around.

Huiyin sighed, "I take care of you every day, and your father only comes to see you once every few days. You really miss him, don't you?"

She was just expressing her feelings, but the wet nurse next to Tonger quickly said, "Your Highness, the princess is still very young and doesn't understand these things."

"Don’t take it to heart. I was just expressing my feelings," Huiyin said, not angry with her daughter. Blood relations were magical that way.

The stewards and wet nurses all smiled. It was very important for them that their master was liked by the Empress. Although the Emperor seemed to treat the princes and princesses well, he listened to the Empress very much.

That’s how it was in the palace. Even a casual remark could lead to many assumptions. So Huiyin remained as usual and didn’t say anything more.

At lunch, both Jing'er and Zhan'er came to eat. Jing'er was talking about Guo Xing's wedding, "He's getting married this month. Mother, please allow me to leave the palace for a while."

"You’re such a lover of excitement. Why don’t you ask your father?" Huiyin shook her head.

Jing'er laughed, "I wouldn’t dare ask Father. He listens to you the most."

"Stop talking nonsense," Huiyin said, but she still interceded with Li Cheng on his behalf.

However, less than an hour after leaving the palace, Jing'er returned with explosive news, "Guo Xing has run away from his wedding."

title: Chapter 92
content:
Chapter 92

◎Update◎

Guo Zhao had risen through the ranks in a perilous environment; he was no ordinary man. He held almost complete control within his household, but never had he imagined that just before going to receive his bride, his son would disappear.

Jiang Bipbo handed him a letter and said, "This is from the heir."

As she spoke, tears welled up in her eyes, and she couldn't help but cover her face and weep. The failed marriage with the Yuwen family would disgrace both households, and she had been the one responsible for arranging the wedding.

Upon reading the letter, Guo Zhao was so furious that he nearly fainted. Jiang Bipbo quickly stepped forward to support him, saying, "My lord, are you alright? Please take care of yourself!"

"This wretch is driving me to madness. I don't know how to resolve this mess now," Guo Zhao felt so dizzy he could barely stand.

Jiang Bipbo then said, "My lord, please allow me to speak frankly. Since things have already reached this point, we should send people to find the heir slowly. We only have this one son. We can't let this push him to his death. If we find him, we should let him stay away for a while, and we, your wife and you, can personally go to the Yuwen family to apologize."

Though Guo Zhao had spoken harshly and threatened to beat Guo Xing to death, Jiang Bipbo's words hit home. To be fair, Guo Xing was quite outstanding, had a good relationship with the crown prince, and was well-versed in both literary and martial arts.

Seeing that Guo Zhao's attitude had softened, Jiang Bipbo continued, "But before that, I need to visit the palace. The crown prince personally attended the ceremony, and now that such a situation has occurred, many matters have reached the palace. If the emperor and empress formed a bad impression of the heir, it would be problematic."

In reality, Jiang Bipbo's relationship with the empress was not as close as outsiders believed. However, she skillfully used this connection to her advantage, always publicly respecting the empress to let others know that her patron was the empress.

With this series of actions, Guo Zhao also considered this to be the best solution.

The next morning, Huiyin heard of Jiang Bipbo's visit to the palace and immediately summoned her. As Jiang Bipbo entered the hall, she knelt down and begged for forgiveness, saying, "It is all my fault. Yesterday, when the crown prince attended the ceremony, such a thing happened in our household."

Huiyin quickly responded, "This is not your fault. Guo Xing just... ran away, leaving you to clean up the mess. How is the Yuwen family?"

"By late yesterday afternoon, he had disappeared. We had to calm the guests and send people to search for him. I have come to the palace to both admit fault and to ask you to send people to search for the heir," Jiang Bipbo said, looking utterly exhausted.

Huiyin, who had also raised Guo Xing, couldn't help but say, "Even though Guo Xing has disappointed you, he’s still young and acted impulsively. Rest assured, after the crown prince returned yesterday, the emperor ordered everyone to keep an eye out."

Jiang Bipbo knelt down again to express her gratitude, saying, "Thank you, Your Highness. We can never repay the great kindness you have shown our family."

Huiyin replied, "Your husband has served the country loyally, and you are like a sister to me. Whether it's for official or personal reasons, we will help wherever we can. As the old saying goes, cultivate oneself, manage the family, and govern the country. It is best for your family matters to be resolved quickly to avoid further gossip."

Jiang Bipbo, hearing that the empress's tone held no blame but only earnest advice, felt relieved. After leaving the palace, she and Guo Zhao went to the Yuwen family to apologize.

Regardless of how humiliated the Yuwen family felt or how they feared that the Yuwen girl might harm herself and thus kept watch over her day and night, the Guo couple apologized sincerely.

Although the two families appeared harmonious on the surface, they could never return to how they were before. Huiyin couldn't help but sigh, "Since there were already dissatisfactions from the start and the marriage was forced, it's no wonder Guo Xing has now joined the army. In a couple of years, when things have settled, we can arrange another marriage."

"Has Fugui sent the items to the Yuwen family?" Huiyin asked.

Fugui replied, "In response to Your Highness, this servant has delivered the pair of fine jade bracelets as instructed and offered some words of comfort."

"Yes, the Yuwen girl has been through a lot," Huiyin said.

Fugui thought to herself that both the Guo and Yuwen families were now vying to curry favor with the empress, which was indeed clever. At her level, some might wonder why she hadn't stopped the marriage from the beginning. But she knew very well that interfering without reason would have made both families resent the empress, which would not have been worth it.

This was the perfect timing.

"Your Highness has a bodhisattva heart," Fugui praised.

Huiyin shook her head, "If I were truly a bodhisattva, I wouldn't be standing here. Anyway, Guo Xing has been sent to the army by Guo Zhao. It will be a life's trial for him."

As they were speaking, they heard a soft clapping sound outside. Huiyin knew it was Li Cheng's arrival and hurriedly stood up to receive him. Fugui and the others prepared to bow as well.

When Li Cheng entered, he led Huiyin back to her seat, saying, "Guo Xing's actions were truly outrageous, but fortunately, he has the resolve to go to the harshest places. This way, the Yuwen family can't say much, and the marriage has been called off." "Actually, it was Guo Furen who handled everything skillfully," Huiyin praised Jiang Bipbo as well.

Li Cheng said, "This shows that forcing things never turns out well. As parents, we should listen more to what our children want."

Huiyin nodded. "That's only natural."

However, Li Cheng soon added, "I heard that Xie Jiuyi and Yin Liyi have come to the capital. It was previously thought that they were missing, but now they have turned up in ragged clothes, seeking refuge with Yin Cifei."

"Do you think they're planning to back the Yuzhang Prince again?" Huiyin asked.

Li Cheng dismissed the concern, "They're already down and out. What do they have to support him with? If they don't even have the confidence to survive, why bother keeping them alive? Besides, it was Yin Cifei who proactively reported the situation to the court, so I can't say much about it."

In truth, Li Cheng was now the ruler of the realm, and he had to be wary of those who still held some power. Xie Jiuyi was no longer a threat, just barely surviving. Li Cheng didn't feel the need to kick him while he was down.

"Well, since the Emperor’s made up his mind, I won’t say anything else. A few days from now, it’ll be my birthday. Have you thought about what gift you’re giving me?" Huiyin coquettishly tried to lighten the mood.

Li Cheng patted his forehead. "I actually forgot about it."

Huiyin poked his forehead. "If you don't give me a gift, I won't talk to you anymore."

"Don't worry, everything is prepared," Li Cheng said with a smile.

At the Yuzhang Prince's mansion, a lively gathering was taking place. Everyone was laughing. Yin Lifang was holding her younger sister's hand and said, "You two should stay at my place for now. After a while, I’ll help you get a proper house, and we’ll all live our lives well."

The two sisters hadn't expected to see each other again. Yin Liyi said, "It’s only been seven or eight years, but it feels like forever since we last saw each other."

Looking at her carefree younger sister, Yin Lifang noticed that her temples had started to gray, even though she wasn't that old. Compared to the Queen, who was of similar age but had jet-black, lustrous hair and a youthful appearance from living in luxury, her sister looked completely different.

"You’ve had a rough few years. It will be better from now on, living by my side," Yin Lifang said with concern.

Yin Liyi thought about the treatment she had endured in the Xie family and couldn't bring herself to tell her sister. Xie Jiuyi's relationship with her had deteriorated to the point of no return, but now that he knew her sister was the Yuzhang Princess, he treated her as before.

It seemed that no relationship could withstand the test of time. She had once thought Xie Jiuyi would always treat her well, but over time, he had grown cold.

"Sister, I don't ask for anything else. I only have one wish, that you help Fangjie find a good marriage. If you can do that, I'll be grateful," Yin Liyi said, having lost interest in everything else.

Seeing her sister's downcast expression, Yin Lifang knew she must have gone through a lot and decided not to pry further.

That night, Yin Liyi returned to the courtyard of the prince's mansion. She hadn't lived in such a luxurious place for a long time, and it felt like a dream. Her husband sat in a reclining chair, still resembling the aristocratic young man he once was. Seeing him, her resentment just melted away.

She used to look down on people who loved wealth and thought she could live in poverty with contentment. But after living in the countryside for so many years, being in such a place now gave her a sense of belonging. She seemed to understand something and then looked at Xie Jiuyi. "In the past, I wrongly blamed you. I always expected a lot from others and thought I didn’t care about fame and fortune. But now, when my sister offered to prepare a house for us and suggested we stay in touch, I didn’t hesitate at all."

Xie Jiuyi had also noticed the change in Yin Liyi. He too couldn't truly accept a life of seclusion. Even without power, living in a bustling area felt more alive.

"Who says otherwise?" After all these years, he was still grateful for his wife's sincerity. Any other woman might have tried to scheme against him.

Yin Liyi looked at him and said, "When we were very young, thanks to the favor of the Wu Prince's wife, we lived in that mansion. Our daily necessities were of the best quality. Later, we learned to read and write, and studied proper etiquette all within the mansion. When we grew up, we went to the Prince of Wei’s mansion. Both my sister and I married into wealthy and prestigious families. In fact, we were always part of the elite, and now we realize that we can't bear any hardship. Isn't that absurd?"

For Xie Jiuyi, it wasn't about whether he could endure hardship. A man without power was like a walking corpse.

Unfortunately, he knew very well that although Li Cheng might have allowed him to seek refuge with the Yuzhang Prince, he would never be given an official position again.

So, he deeply resonated with his wife's words. "It was my incompetence that lost the Wei territory. Once it was taken by others, I fell to this state."

"Let’s leave the past behind and open a few shops to live comfortably," Yin Liyi said with a smile.

Xie Jiuyi nodded heavily.

The author has something to say:

First, let me clarify that some readers have been discussing the female lead. This book was always meant to be a strong female lead story. The female lead, both in her previous life and this one, is more of a dark lotus. She is not the type to be overly kind or empathetic. So, if you find this off-putting, I apologize, but the character's personality was set this way from the beginning.

The reason for not having double updates is that I didn't make any charts this time, and my back has been aching a bit. Consider it a few days of rest. Once I'm on the charts again, I'll try to update more frequently. Please rest assured.

title: Chapter 93
content:
Chapter 93

◎Birthday◎

Huiyin’s birthday was approaching, and of course, now that she was the empress, the birthday was to be called the "Qianqiu Festival." In addition to the customary rewards, Li Cheng privately gave her a hairpin that he had carved himself, saying proudly, “This jade is of excellent quality, and I thought the engraved magnolia flowers would suit you. Don’t dislike it.”

Huiyin immediately put it in her hair, saying, “How could I possibly dislike it? This is your heartfelt gift.”

As the emperor, Li Cheng didn’t have much time to rest. He woke up early to wish his wife a happy birthday and knew that the various titled ladies would soon arrive. He said, “Have fun today. I’ll head to the Duanning Hall first.”

Huiyin wanted to get up to see him off but was stopped. She then had her attendants help her dress, as on such days, formal attire was necessary. If she were to dress shabbily on such an occasion, others might gossip. Even when she was in Xuzhou, no matter how poor the year was, she always dressed elegantly.

This also had to do with each person’s character. Some people were good at overcoming strength with weakness, relying on simplicity, pity, and feigned weakness to make others devoted. But Huiyin believed that human nature was inherently flawed. She was willing to move people with benefits, especially since everyone had a flawed nature. In the short term, people might help out of sympathy, but in the long run, it required an exchange of benefits.

Even with her natal family, she operated the same way. Although she had deep feelings for them, relying solely on emotions to make someone sacrifice everything for her was not feasible. Even if the person agreed, those beneath them might not be willing.

Therefore, she always appeared elegantly in front of others, showing that the position of empress was stable and the position of the crown prince was even more so.

The first to arrive was Huiyin’s family from the Zheng family. Elder Madame Xu, as usual, didn’t come. Huiyin always said she understood that Elder Madame Xu was old and didn’t need to enter the palace, but in reality, it was because they couldn’t stand each other. If Elder Madame Xu were to attend grand occasions and constantly demand things as Huiyin’s grandmother, it would be troublesome. Madame Ji, Xin Shi, and Cui Yuehuan arrived together. They first performed the national ceremony, and Huiyin invited them to sit.

Everyone had changed a lot over the years. Cui Yuehuan had given birth to a son and a daughter, and her figure had become more rounded. Xin Shi had also given birth to another son, and even Madame Ji had added a few more fine lines on her forehead.

Madame Ji inevitably asked about the child, “How come we don’t see the princess?”

“She just got up and is still a little girl who hasn’t had her hair styled yet. But she insists on wearing hairpins like me. So, I asked the imperial clothing bureau to make her a hat with beautiful silk and velvet flowers on it. She was delighted.” Huiyin was puzzled as she wasn’t someone who particularly loved dressing up, but her daughter was completely different and loved beauty at such a young age.

Everyone laughed, and Madame Ji took it quite seriously, “Your Highness, I have some headscarves. How about I offer them to the princess?”

Huiyin quickly waved her hands, “No, no. Please keep those scarves for yourself. The princess is still too young to use them.”

After a few jokes, Huiyin had someone take Xianjie to the imperial garden to play. She couldn’t help but remark to Xin Shi, “The children grow up so fast. Xianjie has blossomed into a graceful young lady and bears a striking resemblance to her mother.”

This was Xin Shi’s proudest achievement, and she tried to suppress her smile, “Thank you for the compliment, Your Majesty. She’s just playful at home. In the future, I’ll need you to guide her more.”

Huiyin smiled, “Of course. Xianjie is my own niece.”

In truth, Huiyin had once considered whether to bring her niece to live with her but ultimately decided against it. Doing so might give others the wrong impression that she intended for Xianjie to be the future empress. There was no such thing as a lasting powerful in-law family. Pei Shuo and the Zheng family had already been rewarded with titles. As long as she was around, the Zheng family would naturally remain at the top, but once she was gone, it would depend on whether the Zheng family could produce capable descendants. If not, that would be their issue, not hers.

Moreover, she later had her own child, Tonger. She could barely give enough love to her own children, let alone share it with someone else’s. If things weren’t handled perfectly, it could breed resentment.

Previously, Xianjie was young, but now that she was older and more understanding, how could she not notice the difference in treatment?

Even with her own children, Huiyin couldn’t ensure they felt completely equal, let alone a niece. So, she decided to give more rewards but not bring anyone into the palace.

Xin Shi felt a little disappointed, but soon news came that both the Cui family and the Jiang family were arriving together. She had no time to dwell on her feelings. It was well known that Lady Jiang and Jiang Bipbo were inseparable, often accompanying each other. However, due to their children’s marriage arrangements, they arrived separately.

Everyone knew the reason but wouldn’t say it out loud.

Soon, everyone had arrived, and Huiyin said the usual pleasantries. Then Madame Ji spoke to Huiyin, “The Cui family has some joyous news, which is why Madam Cui and the eldest granddaughter-in-law are glowing.”

“Oh? What kind of joyous news? Aunt, why is the Cui family so happy?” Huiyin asked.

Madam Cui glanced at Lady Jiang before replying, “Our young master is going to marry Miss Jiang from the Jiang family.”

It turned out that the Cui family’s grandson was preparing to marry the Jiang family’s daughter. No wonder Lady Jiang’s face had cleared of any lingering gloom. The Cui family was a prestigious family among prestigious families and was related to the emperor’s maternal family, with a rank even above the Guo family.

Huiyin immediately responded, congratulating them, “What a perfect match made in heaven. Indeed, it’s a wonderful marriage.”

Everyone thought, ‘No wonder she’s the empress.’ Upon hearing the news, she remained composed, a demeanor not everyone could possess. Jiang Bipbo felt quite upset. The Jiang family’s daughter was now marrying into a higher position, and others might mock the Guo family for failing to recognize true value.

The Yuwen family had kept it tightly under wraps, and now only Madame Ji knew about it.

Congratulatory voices echoed through the hall, and Lady Yuwen finally felt a surge of pride. Blessed with good fortune, her daughter, although a few years older, would not have to serve her in-laws after marrying Cui Xiaolang, the younger son of the Cui family, who was even more handsome than Guo Xing. It was truly a blessing in disguise.

Originally, it was Huiyin's birthday celebration, but now there was an additional joyous event. Even Li Cheng asked Huiyin at night, "I heard that Miss Yuwen is marrying my cousin?"

"Yes, the Cui family is quite good at seizing opportunities. The person you trust the most is Yuwen, and now they are marrying into the Yuwen family. Fortunately, the Yuwen family understands its boundaries. I heard that the Yuzhang Prince might also be interested," Huiyin said. She had learned many things from her usual conversations with these titled ladies.

Li Cheng frowned. "Yuzhang Prince?"

Huiyin quickly added, "Yes, but I only heard that there is interest and it hasn't been made public, which shows that the mother of the Yuzhang Prince is quite sensible. Don't worry, Your Majesty, come, I've been waiting for us to share this birthday noodle together."

A very simple bowl of birthday noodles, just a few green vegetables and an egg, but she had been waiting for him to share this rare moment of warmth together.

"Delicious," Li Cheng praised.

As he ate, his brows remained furrowed, and Huiyin, aware of his many troubles, did not disturb him. She simply had the table cleared after he finished.

After Jiang Bipbo finished dining with Madame Ji, she prepared to leave. Madame Ji said to her, "Don't overthink it. People might gossip for a while, but everyone has their own life, and it will fade with time."

Jiang Bipbo had come specifically to seek Madame Ji's sympathy over her stepson's elopement. She was trying to find a way to truly connect with Madame Ji and the others, and this incident had brought her closer to Madame Ji.

"You are right. I am young and have never experienced such things. I always worry about how everyone views us, but with your guidance, I feel much better," Jiang Bipbo spoke skillfully.

Madame Ji thought to herself that her eloquence was quite good and felt rather proud.

After Jiang Bippo left, Madame Ji entered and told Zheng Fang, "As a stepmother, she is endlessly worried. I told her it doesn't concern her."

"It concerns her a lot. Actually, what relation does her stepson have to her?" Zheng Fang, who had been inept in his own governance, now saw things clearly from outside the situation.

Madame Ji didn't understand. "Then why does it matter?"

"Are you silly? The matter of the Crown Prince's marriage is of utmost importance. Although the Crown Prince is not yet of age to select a wife, families always look ahead a few years. As the mother of the Empress, who else would the Empress ask for advice on selecting a wife for her son?" Zheng Fang had previously helped in the selection of a Crown Princess for his daughters, and he knew the intricacies well. He had sent a lot of money to the mother and sister-in-law of the late Madame Ji.

Madame Ji suddenly realized. "I have always thought well of everyone. I used to be cautious, but now that my children are doing well, I have let my guard down. However, the Empress is very independent, and I can't influence her decisions."

"Outsiders don't know these things. They think the Empress is very filial and that you have a say," Zheng Fang said, yawning as his craving for alcohol returned. He sniffed.

Madame Ji thought that she had always been a simple person. If not for her many trials, she would not have developed any scheming nature. Now that life was good, she had relaxed.

While she had relaxed, the Yuzhang Prince's Mansion had not. Yin Lifang had heard that Miss Yuwen had not been married off and, although she had doubts, saw an opportunity. After all, the power behind Miss Yuwen was too tempting.

The residents of the Yuzhang Prince's Mansion appeared as wealthy idlers but held no real power. Noble families in the capital actually looked down on them. The next generation would only be ordinary members of the royal family, as the current dynasty practiced graded inheritance, and after a few generations, they would become commoners.

Unexpectedly, Xie Jiuyi had stopped her, and now that the Yuwen and Cui families were marrying, there was a lot of buzz outside.

Yin Liyi could now discern her sister's thoughts, and she added, "Sister, not marrying into the Yuwen family is actually a good thing. High-ranking families marry in, and low-ranking families marry out. You have never been on good terms with the Princess Wei, and because of the dowry, the princess almost emptied the mansion. If you find someone from a slightly lower family who is clever, they will be loyal to you in the future. If they have too much backing and are overly compliant, how can they truly respect you?"

title: Chapter 94
content:
Chapter 94

◎Means◎

After the celebrations, it was time for envoys from various countries to come and pay tribute. For such an occasion, Li Cheng asked Huiyin to accompany him. It wasn't because he doted on her endlessly, but because he trusted that Huiyin wouldn't try to seize power as others speculated.

For her, seizing power would be too easy. If she brought him a bowl of soup, he would drink it without hesitation, even without anyone testing it for poison.

"This is the first time foreign envoys are visiting. We should show off the grandeur of our great empire," Li Cheng said with a smile.

Huiyin knew that Li Cheng's heart was clear and straightforward. Otherwise, why would he, at his age, still talk so naively and compete with others? She looked at him and said, "In these tributary events, we usually give more than we receive. We need to be careful. Our people’s lives aren’t exactly easy right now."

If he weren't someone so close to her, Huiyin might not have spoken so honestly. Still, she was careful not to hurt his confidence and only added, "This time, thanks to you, we get to see so many people. I wonder if the Shengping Bureau's dance is ready."

"Don’t worry, everything is ready, and I’ve personally reviewed the music," Li Cheng said meticulously.

Seeing him still sitting in the Duanning Hall, Huiyin couldn't help but say, "You've been sitting all day. Why don't we take a walk? I used to sit for long periods, and it made me uncomfortable. After I tried horse riding, I almost hurt my back. You used to train outside so often, and now, sitting all day, you should at least walk a few steps."

With Huiyin's suggestion, Li Cheng obediently let her lead him out. Outside, in the imperial garden, flowers bloomed, and butterflies and bees lingered. Somehow, he was reminded of his time in Xuzhou.

"Huiyin, do you remember our mansion?" Li Cheng suddenly asked.

"How could I forget? When I first arrived, I loved the garden at Huaiyin Mansion the most. Without it, how would I have gotten through those days alone?" Huiyin felt dazed recalling the past—too much happiness made time fly. She wished it could slow down, even more.

Granny Chao and Yun Hui felt like they belonged to another lifetime.

Those once fearful and anxious days now seemed to have a different meaning when looked back on.

However, before the couple could reminisce much longer, they heard that the Empress Dowager had suddenly fainted. Huiyin and Li Cheng exchanged glances and rushed over.

Although the Empress Dowager occasionally had minor ailments, they weren't severe. This time, since she fainted, the couple immediately summoned the imperial doctor.

The doctor spoke tactfully, but Huiyin understood the meaning. Because of her age and strict vegetarian diet, her energy and blood flow were weak, leading to her fainting. After the doctor prescribed medicine, Li Cheng called for Qin An and instructed, "The Empress Dowager's diet needs to be proper. She's old, and you can't let her have her way."

Qin An, being the chief steward, knew what to do upon Li Cheng's instruction.

However, why was the Empress Dowager on a vegetarian diet? It was said to be for Li Cheng's sake. She knew her grandson had been fighting for many years, with much killing, and she used this method to atone for it.

Huiyin's first reaction was to think, isn't this just a way to gain favor? Like pretending to hang yourself to get attention or fainting to pray for the emperor's well-being. These tricks were suitable for concubines seeking favor, but for an Empress Dowager, even if she noticed something, it wasn't appropriate to say anything.

She understood the principle of not interfering in family matters. Previously, the Empress Dowager, thinking of her grandson, didn't hide anything. Now that she did, Huiyin could see that Li Cheng wouldn't suspect these things.

Sure enough, Li Cheng sighed, "Grandmother, why did you do this?"

Huiyin also showed concern, "Yes, I believe grandmother's sincerity is a good thing, but it's not right to harm her body like this. I remember she liked a girl from the Xun family. Having that girl accompany her would give us peace of mind."

Better to bring it up ourselves rather than let others do it, making any pretense of fainting useless.

Li Cheng smiled, "This is a good idea. You have Tonger to take care of you now, so you can't accompany her for long." He didn’t want his wife to be there. In-laws often clash, and spending too much time together would only make things worse. He loved Huiyin, but his grandmother was still his grandmother, inseparable.

Both sides gave each other a step down, quite satisfied.

At that time, the Xun family was having a meal together. Princess Jianjia had just married into the family. Due to her special status, she usually didn't dine with everyone. But she didn't dare to put on airs either. When she married, Princess Wei advised her that although she was of royal lineage, the Xun family was also related to the emperor, and there was still the Empress Dowager in the palace, so she needed to respect Madam Xun on the surface.

Of course, the current title holder was Madam Xun's eldest son, while her husband was Madam Xun's youngest son.

Madam Xun, who once schemed to drive away Xun Rou, could hardly be considered a benevolent woman, but now appeared kind-faced. "Tomorrow, we'll go to the temple to burn incense together."

Jianjia, being astute, quickly said, "I'll come with you."

"Very well," Lady Xun said, then turned to her granddaughter, Xun Jiying: "Child, you need not go with us. A woman should prioritize chastity and tranquility."

Xun Jiying was quite different from Xun Rou. Xun Rou was truly ruthless, doing anything without any limits, but Xun Jiying, born into wealth and raised in a noble household, often read books and wrote, making her exceptionally dignified. She was eight when she left the palace that year, and now she is ten. She naturally understood why her grandmother spoke to her this way—not to make her chaste and tranquil, but to prevent her from getting into trouble.

The Xun family used to be just a minor official's family, rising to their current status only through the support of the Grand Empress Dowager. However, the Grand Empress Dowager is very old, and if she passes away, the Xun family will lose their standing in the capital. The Emperor has his own maternal relatives, the Cui family, and the Empress's mother's family, the Zheng family, holds two titles. The Cui and Zheng families have long been connected by marriage.

If Jiying can enter the palace and become the Crown Princess in the future, it could secure the Xun family's prosperity for generations.

As the saying goes, those closest to the water get the moon first. With the Grand Empress Dowager in the palace, there is always an opportunity.

"Yes," Xun Jiying replied respectfully.

Lady Xun's mother-in-law, seeing her daughter unable to go out for a long time, felt sorry for her and said to Lady Xun: "I heard the Yuwen family is hosting a poetry gathering. Why don't we let Jiying go and play? They have already sent an invitation."

Lady Xun smiled and said, "The Yuwen family's daughter is about to marry into the Cui family, so they are quite pleased. If she wants to go, let her go."

Unfortunately, before she could go, someone from the palace arrived, saying they wanted to bring Xun Jiying to the palace to accompany the Grand Empress Dowager. The Xun family was overjoyed, while Xun Jiying felt both delighted and apprehensive.

She first went to meet the Empress in the Linded Hall, the most splendid place in the entire palace. The glazed tiles, the arched eaves adorned with numerous flowers, and the animal-shaped incense burners emitting wisps of blue smoke all added to its grandeur. After passing through the crystal curtains, she knelt down to pay her respects.

"Rise," Empress Huizheng said with a smile.

Xun Jiying stood up: "Thank you, Your Majesty, for summoning me to accompany the Grand Empress Dowager."

Empress Huizheng looked at her: "You are still a child. In a few days, envoys from various countries will be coming to the palace, so you can come out and play. The Grand Empress Dowager is quite old, so you don't really need to take care of her; there are servants for that. Just keep her company and chat with her. I have already arranged your allowance, and if you need anything, just ask Qin An."

At her age, a young girl might feel some embarrassment, not wanting to flatter others or do things against her will. But girls mature early and understand the expectations of adults, so they try to meet those expectations.

Empress Huizheng didn't really have any ill intentions toward her. People should strive when they can, but there's no need to humiliate others. The marriages of the Crown Prince and the Second Prince are ultimately decided by the adults. As long as the parents are not foolish, what can others do?

"Thank you for your consideration, Empress Dowager." Xun Jiying could understand the meaning behind the Empress Dowager's words.

Huiyin smiled and said, "Go ahead."

The palace maid Baochan, who was in service at the Empress Dowager's quarters, came to fetch Xun Jiying. Along the way, neither of them dared to speak much, as palace rules were strict, and even casual conversations could attract unwanted attention and be considered improper.

At the palace entrance, Baochan said, "Miss Xun, the Empress Dowager is still asleep. Recently, she has often been eating vegetarian meals, which has made her feel weak. The Emperor has asked us to encourage her to eat more meat. So, we will trouble you, Miss Xun."

Xun Jiying felt somewhat uneasy. At home, she was the young mistress and, being a child, everyone doted on her. But here in the palace, although she was only ten years old, everyone treated her like an adult.

After they entered, Nanny Fan waved them over. "Go and rest in the side hall for now. The Empress Dowager has not woken up yet."

Xun Jiying went to rest in the side hall, but as soon as she left, the Empress Dowager woke up.

Nanny Fan, surprised and delighted, said, "Ancestor, you've finally woken up. The Emperor and Empress Dowager both came to visit you. How are you feeling now?"

At her age, even small ailments could cause discomfort. Upon hearing that Li Cheng had visited, the Empress Dowager felt some relief. She had lost all standing in the imperial harem. Even the things she received were far inferior to those of the Empress Dowager in Linde Hall. So this time, she hadn't told anyone and had set up this whole situation.

Even Nanny Fan had been kept in the dark. The Empress Dowager held her forehead, "I'm still feeling a little unwell."

Nanny Fan quickly said, "There's medicine just brewed in the tea room. I'll have someone bring it for you, Ancestor."

"That medicine tastes awful," the Empress Dowager said, leaning back on the cushion, looking rather unhappy.

Nanny Fan said, "You can't skip your medicine, Ancestor. The Emperor would surely blame us. He's coming over for dinner again tonight."

Hearing this, the Empress Dowager brightened up. Last time, the Emperor had sent her great-grandnephew's daughter away, which had been quite embarrassing. If this time, she could bring her family back into the palace through this situation, it would be perfect. That Princess Zheng was slippery; when she had suggested that her niece Xianjie come into the palace, she could have brought her family in too. But Princess Zheng had said it was against propriety, leaving no opportunity. This time, however, there was a chance.

Seeing the Empress Dowager's mood lift, Nanny Fan quickly added, "And, the Empress Dowager has summoned Miss Xun to keep you company. She's resting in the side hall now. We, the older servants, can't come up with anything new to entertain you, so Miss Xun is here to accompany you."

She had expected the Empress Dowager to be pleased, but instead, her face flushed with a mix of emotions.

title: Chapter 95
content:
Chapter 95

◎The Emperor's Brothers◎

In the center of the True Appraisal Hall, a group of dancers from the Shengping Bureau were dancing. They spun gracefully on their toes, their movements elegant and fluid, while the music of string and wind instruments filled the air. Li Cheng was hosting a reception for envoys from various countries. It was also the first time Huiyin had seen so many people of different ethnicities. The envoys from Goryeo and the Southern Barbarians performed the same courtesies as the Han people, and they looked similar. However, people from Zhenla and Sanfoqi had slightly darker skin but striking big eyes and eyebrows.

At this grand occasion, Empress Dowager Huiyin, Xun Jiying, and some noble ladies were in attendance. Some attendees couldn’t help but whisper among themselves that the emperor’s harem only had the Empress, making it seem cold and desolate. But of course, they didn’t dare voice these thoughts aloud.

Even if they had, Huiyin wouldn’t have minded too much.

The most exhausting thing in life is living up to others' expectations. She whispered to Li Cheng, “This dance is beautifully choreographed.”

Li Cheng smiled faintly, “It’s good as long as it looks good.”

Though Li Cheng appeared carefree now, he had secretly learned some Goryeo and Zhenla. Huiyin was quite proud when she heard him casually speak a few words.

“My emperor is extremely wise.”

Li Cheng shook his head, “These are just minor skills. The key is to govern our country well. Only then will foreign states truly respect us.”

Huiyin nodded in agreement. The couple appeared radiant during the banquet, but when they returned to Linde Hall, they both collapsed on the bed, not wanting to get up.

“You have no idea how much my back hurts; I can’t even straighten up. I sat for too long,” Huiyin complained, leaning on a cushion. She disliked the medicinal patches, finding their smell overpowering.

Li Cheng was in a similar state. Having been involved in wars from a young age, he now had to work hard to govern the country. Often sitting for an entire day, his old wounds would flare up, making him uncomfortable. But he only let his guard down and showed his discomfort when alone with Huiyin.

Seeing Huiyin wincing in pain, he couldn’t help but say, “Should I get some medicinal oil and massage it for you?”

“No need. The more you massage, the worse it gets. A couple of days' rest will be fine. But I can rest. What about you?” Huiyin said worriedly, looking at her husband.

Li Cheng grinned, “Don’t worry. With you caring so much about me, I’m already feeling better.”

“Silly,” Huiyin said, calling for someone to bring a hot towel for him. Thinking about how hard Li Cheng had worked as emperor, sacrificing enjoyment for duty, her heart ached.

But if they said they were tired, people outside would surely accuse them of complaining without reason. Li Cheng understood this, so he worked even harder to govern the country well, to leave a foundation for their sons and to ensure the people of this generation would no longer suffer from the horrors of war.

When these delegations arrived, Shangjing became extremely lively. Even the young ladies who usually stayed secluded in their homes came out. Xianjie and Shi Jie from the Guo family went out together. Their relationship had always been good. Xianjie was two or three years older than Shi Jie and frequently visited the Zheng family with Jiang Bipbo. The two were almost like best friends.

“Sister Pei, look over there—someone’s breathing fire!” Shi Jie, though not young, spoke logically.

Being a young girl herself, Xianjie immediately agreed and asked the coachman to head to Kaiguo Temple.

However, their financial situations were different. Jiang Bipbo had grown up in wealth, with money to spare, and after marrying Guo Zhao, she managed to balance the education of a noble lady and a merchant’s daughter for her daughter. To make friends, one had to be generous, especially with Shi Jie, who was a young lady of a thousand gold. She always carried promissory notes worth a thousand taels and had gold beans and pearls in her purse.

In contrast, Xianjie relied solely on her modest monthly allowance of two taels, rarely buying anything on her own, usually depending on her mother, Xin Shi, to get her jewelry.

Seeing Shi Jie spend two hundred taels on jade in an instant, Xianjie couldn’t match that and said she wouldn’t buy anything for now.

When she returned home and saw Xin Shi, Xianjie remained visibly upset.

Xin Shi couldn’t help but ask, “What’s wrong? You went out to have fun; why are you upset?”

“It’s nothing. There were just too many people today, and I felt a bit suffocated in crowded places,” Xianjie said, not wanting to explain too much to her mother.

But it was easy for Xin Shi to find out what had happened. Back in her room, Xin Shi discreetly questioned the servants who had accompanied Xianjie. Upon learning the reason, she couldn’t help but complain, “You all should have come to me for some money. How could you let our daughter lose face in public?”

Xianjie’s steward said, “Our family is a noble family, and our rules are like this. It wouldn’t be proper for a young lady of a noble family to appear like a nouveau riche. It’s not our girl’s fault.”

Xin Shi lowered her eyes. "In my opinion, the Guo family is currently troubled by the Yuwen family's affairs. I see that Lady Guo is the Empress Dowager's sworn sister. We may allow them to spend time together for now, but in the future, let's not encourage it. Later, I'll send two famous paintings to her. At her age, she should focus more on reading and appreciating art."

Managing money as a head of household is a concern for the future. A young lady is most carefree during her years in the boudoir. Once she becomes a mistress, she'll worry about the household every day. So, while she can play for now, she should enjoy it.

The steward said, "But our young lady and Miss Guo have planned to play polo together in the future."

"We can always decline later. Attending one out of every three invitations should suffice," Xin Shi replied.

Hearing this, the steward felt relieved and left.

Unaware of this, Shi Jie was sharing with Jiang Biqbo, "Those jade pieces were beautiful. It seemed like Xianjie wasn’t very interested, so I bought a few pieces to have carved and given to my parents."

Hearing this, Jiang Biqbo felt uneasy. She thought, as the Empress Dowager's niece, Xianjie's prospects of becoming Crown Princess or a royal consort were likely ruined due to their elopement situation. Originally, she had no desire for such status, being content as a countess with her background. However, since Guo Zhao often mentioned it, she also felt it was a pity.

Shi Jie, as a young lady from a marquis' family, had both looks and talent. With a steward attending to her and being taught household management, she was more than capable of being a royal consort. Marrying someone ordinary would actually be a waste of her talents.

Therefore, Jiang Biqbo thought that compared to the Pei family’s wealth, her daughter's extravagant purchases might come across as flaunting.

"Shi Jie, in the future, you can spend as much as you like, but try not to show off in front of your friends," Jiang Biqbo said.

Shi Jie didn't understand. "Mother, why do you say this?"

Jiang Biqbo chuckled. Indeed, children's interactions shouldn't be restricted by adults; she was becoming overly meticulous.

"Mother is just giving you a casual reminder; you don't have to follow everything I say. By the way, last time we went boating with the Empress Dowager, we went to the palace together. You also entered the palace. How did you find it?"

Asking this, she heard Shi Jie say, "There are indeed too many rules in the palace, aside from other things. The Empress Dowager changed her outfits three times during our visit. If she didn't give the order, the curtains would remain drawn, and no one dared to make noise. I felt really stifled. Also, the banquet—the banquet looked plentiful and elegant, but the sweet cakes were tasteless. We avoided eating the bone-in meats for fear of making noise."

Jiang Biqbo had never considered palace life from her daughter's perspective. Perhaps because of her merchant background, losing her parents young made her feel like a floating weed. She always believed that having power and influence ensured a good life, as wealth alone could easily be taken away.

Thus, she had a psychological dependence on the Empress Dowager. Moreover, the Empress Dowager's conduct was very methodical, and her two sons were intelligent. So, her agreement wasn't entirely due to status, as her husband thought, but because she believed the Empress Dowager would be an excellent mother-in-law.

But she hadn't realized her daughter didn't long for palace life.

"So, you suffered in the palace."

Shi Jie smiled. "We were considered lucky. We only enter the palace a few times a year. Miss Xun Jiying from the Xun family has it worse. The Empress Dowager's health is poor, and she still has to enter the palace like entering a cage."

Jiang Biqbo was stunned.

After the foreign envoys left, Li Cheng didn't go to the Duanning Hall but rested well for two days in the Linde Hall. Huiyin took care of him the whole time, and they ate and slept together, even playing with their child.

Li Cheng couldn't help but say, "You see, after resting for a few days, I feel full of energy. But you, who used to love riding, haven't played polo since your waist injury. It's a pity."

"Look at what you're saying. We have you in the family. Why do you always insist I ride?" Huiyin pinched his nose, finding his words particularly endearing.

In truth, he felt Huiyin should be free-spirited and refreshing. He feared she'd get bored cooped up in the palace, not knowing that Huiyin loved lying down. She was content because she had struggled in her youth, and now she didn't need to make friends through activities like polo.

The couple indulged for a while before going to see the Empress Dowager. Before they entered, they heard a clear voice reciting Buddhist scriptures.

"It should be Miss Xun reciting," Huiyin said.

Li Cheng smiled, and they entered. Xun Jiying's voice stopped as she stood up to greet them. After the imperial couple allowed her to rise, Xun Jiying withdrew.

"How is the Empress Dowager's health?" Li Cheng asked first.

The Empress Dowager was delighted to see Li Cheng come to pay his respects, as the Emperor only visited a few times a month and not often. She hurriedly said, "I am already better, and I must thank the Emperor for your concern."

"It seems that bringing Miss Xun into the palace was the right decision; Your Majesty’s complexion has improved greatly," Huiyin smiled.

Truly, mentioning what shouldn’t be mentioned, the Empress Dowager had caused such a commotion precisely for this reason. However, these tactics were ineffective in Huiyin's eyes. Because Li Cheng, out of respect for the Empress Dowager, had already shown exceptional favor to the Xun family. In the early days of the dynasty, granting them land and salaries came from tax revenues, when the state was in dire need of funds for numerous projects. Yet, the Empress Dowager still wanted perpetual wealth and was never content.

Li Cheng also looked at Huiyin, "Indeed, all her provisions can be compared to those of a county or duchess, treating her as if she were at home in the palace."

Such care for her maternal relatives naturally pleased the Empress Dowager. However, Li Cheng continued, "I plan to take the Empress, Crown Prince, and others on a tour of the capital region, which may last a month. If there is anything you need, Grandmother, just let Qin An know."

This had been decided long ago by Li Cheng. Unlike the Wei King, who enjoyed annual hunts to display his martial prowess, such activities often led to accidents during actual hunts.

Now, the court had established a system for selecting military officials through examinations, eliminating the need for the Emperor to take personal risks. He thought that his children, having grown up in luxury, had no idea how people lived outside the palace, so he wanted to take them out to see the world.

Clearly, the Empress Dowager, nearing her seventies, was not suitable for travel. She sighed, having hoped that bringing Xun Jiying into the palace would give her an advantage, but now the Emperor was planning to leave.

Even Huiyin did not know about the trip until they left the Empress Dowager’s palace. She then said, "We’re really going out to play?"

"Why not? When you were a princess, I took you back to visit my family. Now that you are Empress, should we confine ourselves to the palace every day? This is why I want you to learn to ride," Li Cheng, now as Emperor, found less time to talk with Huiyin, always hoping to maintain their closeness as before.

Huiyin clapped her hands and laughed, "So you were teasing me. I can ride, but only if we ride together."

"Shh, keep it down," Li Cheng whispered guiltily.

Huiyin found it increasingly amusing to tease him, even as Emperor, he could still blush.

When they told Jing'er and Zhan'er about the trip, the two children were almost jumping with joy. Tong'er, not understanding what the trip meant, simply clung to Huiyin, clapping along with her brothers' cheers, as if that was the way to join in.

Jing'er said, "Mother, will Second Brother and I ride horses or take a carriage? I want to ride a horse."

At ten years old, he always felt like he was more mature than his age. On regular days, Li Cheng discussed state affairs with him, making him feel different from other teenagers. However, his idea was immediately rejected by Huiyin: "It's still cold outside, and you shouldn't risk catching a chill. Since this is a trip for fun, you should sit in the carriage and enjoy the scenery. If you ride a horse, many people will have to protect you. What if someone shoots a hidden arrow?"

"Hidden arrow? With so many people protecting me, would there still be hidden arrows?" Jing'er didn't understand.

Huiyin smiled: "That's why they say, 'A child of wealth should avoid danger,' meaning you shouldn’t take unnecessary risks. If you were just an ordinary person, Li Jing, I wouldn't care if you galloped around. In fact, I would be proud of you. But you are the Crown Prince, a child of great worth. If anything happens to you, it’s not just me losing a son—it’s the empire losing its future leader. Your father's kingdom might even be jeopardized."

Even though Jing'er had been studying both civil and military strategies, his parents treated him with great respect. Even the eunuchs and maids in the palace were chosen by him. However, there were times when Huiyin would directly tell him when he was wrong.

Being a sensible child, Jing'er acknowledged his mistake after hearing Huiyin's words: "I understand, mother. Thank you for the reminder."

"Don't mind me for being talkative," Huiyin said, always mindful of her words. Her son was growing up, and she couldn't discipline him like a little child anymore. If she did, it might create opportunities for others to take advantage.

Seeing Zhan'er looking gloomy, Huiyin knew her words might have upset him, but there was nothing that could be done. Unless Jing'er were unusually mediocre and Zhan'er exceptionally talented, the eldest son of the empress would naturally inherit the throne.

Life was full of disappointments. Even Huiyin, despite having everything good now, still suffered from minor aches and pains. Whether it was her period causing discomfort or her legs aching, she kept these issues private.

Maybe sensing what Huiyin was thinking, Jing'er turned to Zhan'er and said, "I remember someone gave me a Khitan saddle, which actually seems more suitable for you. Mom’s right. We can’t ride horses on the journey, but once we get to the summer palace, we can."

Khitan saddles were renowned as the finest in the world. Although they were princes, Huiyin and Li Cheng did not raise their children to be prodigal. They only replaced items when they were broken.

Sure enough, upon hearing this, Zhan'er happily said, "Thank you, Crown Prince."

Jing'er patted his younger brother on the shoulder: "Why are you thanking me? I've been wanting to give it to you. I was just looking for a reason. Now it's settled, I can give it to you."

Huiyin was pleased with Jing'er’s thoughtfulness: "You see, your elder brother always thinks of you when he has good things. By the way, I have some frosted preserved cherries here. This morning, I told Nanny Nan to save them for you."

She wasn’t sure how to comfort her younger son, but she knew he’d have to learn to accept such realities as he grew up. Zhan'er was more open-minded than she thought. Although he sometimes got upset by certain words, after eating the cherries, his mood improved, and he even took Tonger out to play. Jing'er followed, and they played together.

He told Li Cheng these thoughts in the evening: "Our second son shows his happiness openly, which is good, but I still feel a bit guilty. Only one of our two sons can have ultimate power, while the other must always be a subordinate. And it just so happens that Zhan'er is smart, not some fool."

Li Cheng had never thought about these issues; he loves both his sons equally. "You're overthinking things, right?"

"No, I'm not overthinking it. There are many things we can’t foresee, even if we prepare ahead of time. What I mean is, if we spoil Zhan'er too much, Jing'er might resent it when he becomes ruler. How many royal brothers actually get along well? But if we favor Jing'er and ignore Zhan'er, that would be too harsh." Huiyin found this dilemma hard to solve.

Li Cheng put his hands behind his head, feeling troubled after listening to her. But then an idea struck him.

title: Chapter 96
content:
Chapter 96

◎Incognito Inspection Tour◎

Until the imperial procession left, Huiyin begged Li Cheng to tell her what method he was using, but he refused to say.

"Mother, Mother, look, that's a moo-moo..."

A child's voice interrupted her thoughts. It was her daughter speaking. The child, who had never left the palace in her two years, was making a fuss over seeing a water buffalo.

Huiyin smiled and said, "That's not a moo-moo, that's a cow. Cows can be used for plowing fields and can also pull carts. Look, there's a cowherd riding on top of it."

"The cowherd rides the yellow cow, the song echoes through the forest shade. Intending to catch a chirping cicada, he suddenly closes his mouth and stands still." Tonger suddenly said.

Huiyin was surprised and said, "My daughter is really amazing. I didn't teach her many times, but she already memorized it. She has such a good memory."

In their free time in the palace, Huiyin taught her daughter poetry just as she did with her two sons. Jing'er and Zhan'er were also cheering for their sister. They both adored Tonger without any hint of jealousy. The two boys were playing a game of Go at the moment and continued their game after cheering. The carriage was spacious enough for her to comfortably manage all three children.

Since Huiyin was so eager to know Li Cheng's method, she even probed her sons, "Has your father said anything to you recently?"

Jing'er had just placed a piece and looked at Huiyin, nodding heavily.

"What did he say?" Huiyin continued to ask.

Jing'er thought for a moment, seeing his brother still pondering, then looked at Huiyin and said, "He said a lot. He mentioned that this trip is about observing the people's lives, and I shouldn't act like a Crown Prince, but rather speak less and observe more."

Zhan'er, who had been thinking, added, "Yes, Father told us the same thing."

Huiyin forced herself to resist the urge to roll her eyes. "That's it...?"

It didn’t seem like any great strategy, so she didn’t ask further and continued to accompany Tonger in looking outside. Outside looked nothing like the palace. It was autumn harvest season, and the rice fields swaying in the breeze outside looked so inviting.

Since Li Cheng took the throne, all regions were required to report hidden farmland, but this touched the interests of many large landowners. For them, regime changes meant nothing, but touching their land was like creating an enmity. Some incited commoners to make trouble at government offices, while others deliberately bribed ministers heavily to speak on their behalf.

In fact, Li Cheng’s days were not easy. He aimed to consolidate military power and redistribute land to the commoners, but instead, unrest erupted among the populace.

The tour didn’t venture far, just around the capital, intending for his sons to inherit his legacy. He didn’t want them to be misled by the gentry if one day he passed away.

By evening, they arrived at the temporary palace. This was originally the previous emperor’s palace for recuperation. Li Cheng, being frugal, did not have it renovated but only arranged for some defense, cleaning, and basic setup. The five of them moved in.

Jing’er and Zhan’er stayed in the palace opposite theirs. The couple stayed with their daughter. After arriving at the temporary palace, Li Cheng whispered to Huiyin, "There’s a hot spring here. Go freshen up, and we’ll go soak in it."

"Hot spring?" Huiyin, who had been feeling very tired, brightened up at the mention of it.

Li Cheng smiled. "Indeed. I’ve heard you’ve been uncomfortable for so long. Ever since you married me, you’ve endured hardships—traveling, giving birth to our children. Even though you seem to live in luxury, you've truly been enduring hardships, anxious and unable to sleep peacefully. How could your body be in good shape? We’ll soak in the hot spring, and tomorrow we’ll have some ginseng chicken soup. The day after, we’ll go out for a walk. Everything will be fine."

While other emperors might feel they have the world at their fingertips, Li Cheng was filled with anxiety. He feared that his wife might not be able to stay with him forever and worried that many of his well-intentioned actions might be too radical, leading to bigger problems in the future.

Only Huiyin could truly understand his inner turmoil.

While the children were asleep, they crept to the hot spring pool like thieves. The servants wisely retreated. Li Cheng wrapped his arms around his wife. She wore a delicate garment embroidered with carp playing among lotuses, which made her skin appear even more flawless. He couldn’t resist and pulled it down...

The hot spring water gushed over Huiyin’s body. She stood up and deliberately blocked the water with her waist, experiencing an unparalleled sense of relaxation.

Li Cheng, having grown up in the Jiangnan region, was excellent at swimming. Huiyin could swim too, but not as freely as Li Cheng. They splashed water playfully until late into the night before heading back.

As a result, when they woke up, the sun was already setting. She touched her head. "I’ve slept nearly a full day!"

Fugui carried a bowl of soup over and said, "Empress, you've finally woken up. The emperor has taken the Crown Prince and the Second Prince out. The princess came by earlier, but when she saw you were asleep, the stewardess took her out to play."

Huiyin, who usually didn't feel like eating ginseng chicken soup, finished the entire bowl clean, likely because she was hungry.

As soon as she finished, the two boys came in with flushed faces. Zhan'er had a bow and arrow on his back, and surprisingly, Jing'er was carrying two rabbits. After wiping her mouth with a handkerchief, Huiyin couldn't help but laugh and said, "Oh wow, you two actually brought that in here. This isn't a hunting ground, you know."

Jing'er quickly replied, "It was my fault. Today, Father took us hunting nearby. I shot two rabbits and wanted to bring them for you to see, Mother."

"Impressive, truly impressive. Zhan'er, did you shoot anything?" Huiyin asked hurriedly.

Zhan'er shook his head. "I didn't."

Huiyin smiled and said, "Don't be discouraged. You're younger than your brother, yet. When the time comes, you'll definitely be able to do it."

Zhan'er nodded heavily and added, "Mother, Father and Elder Brother also said the same. But I heard that Elder Brother was able to shoot rabbits at the age of six, so I'm still not as good as him."

"You can't say it like that. Your brother has his strengths, and you have yours," Huiyin understood Li Cheng's intentions. A real comparison, though harsh, was the most effective.

Jing'er chimed in, "Yes, Mother, don't worry. I'll teach my younger brother."

"Well, that's good," Huiyin gently touched her younger son's face.

Zhan'er felt a bit ashamed and said, "Sometimes I want to surpass my older brother, but he always wants to help."

"Of course, after all, you two are your father's right and left arms. How could any outside officials be as trustworthy as you?" Huiyin said with a smile.

At dinner, there was braised rabbit meat, and the family ate heartily. Li Cheng was talking to Huiyin, "You've rested enough. Tomorrow, we'll go out in disguise together."

"Alright, tomorrow I won't wear hairpins, a scarf should be fine," Huiyin, who had rarely dressed as a commoner when she wasn't Empress, found it novel.

Seeing her like this, Li Cheng said, "You're still like a child."

As the children ate heartily, Huiyin quietly spoke to Li Cheng, "Now that we've left, I wonder what's happening in the capital? Are you worried?"

She was the kind who feared someone might usurp the throne if she let go of control. Before Li Cheng was in the capital, she was there. Now that they were all out, the Empress Dowager was useless and knew nothing in the capital.
